spatialpy.core package¶

Submodules¶

spatialpy.core.boundarycondition module¶

class spatialpy.core.boundarycondition.BoundaryCondition(xmin=None, xmax=None, ymin=None, ymax=None, zmin=None, zmax=None, type_id=None, deterministic=True, target=None, value=None, model=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Set spatial regions of the domain where a property of particles are held constant (updated each simulation step)

Conditions (one or more of the following must be set):

  • xmin, xmax: (float) min or max value in the x dimension

  • ymin, ymax: (float) min or max value in the y dimension

  • zmin, zmax: (float) min or max value in the z dimension

  • type_id: type (subdomain) of the partciles

Targets (one of the following must be set):

property: (str), ‘nu’, ‘rho’,’v’ species: (str) name of a chemical species. Must also set deterministic=True/False flag.

Parameters:

  • xmin (float) – x-axis coordinate lower bound of condition

  • xmax (float) – x-axis coordinate upper bound of condition

  • ymin (float) – y-axis coordinate lower bound of condition

  • ymax (float) – y-axis coordinate upper bound of condition

  • zmin (float) – z-axis coordinate lower bound of condition

  • zmax (float) – z-axis coordinate upper bound of condition

  • type_id (int | str) – Set condition to particle type id

  • deterministic (bool) – Must be set if target is Species. Set True if boundary condition target is species and applies to deterministic simulation. BoundaryCondition not yet implemeneted for Stochastic Species.

  • target (str) – Set target to properties, can be ‘nu’ ‘rho’ or ‘v’ or species name If species name, determinstic must also be set to True/False.

  • value (float or float[3]) – Value property will take in region defined by the conditions

  • model (spatialpy.core.model.Model) – Target model of boundary condition

expression()[source]¶

Creates evaluable string expression of boundary condition.

Returns:

A string representation of the boundary condition.

Return type:

str

Bases: object

Abstract class used to constuct the data function.

Parameters:

name (str) – Name of the Data Function.

Raises:

DataFunctionError – If a name is not provided.

map(point)[source]¶

This method must be overridden by the DataFunction subclass.

NOTE: The spatial location is evaulated at t=0 and is not re-evaluated as the fluid domain moves over time.

Parameters:

point (float[3]) – The x, y, z position.

Returns:

Value of function at this spatial location.

Return type:

float

spatialpy.core.domain module¶

class spatialpy.core.domain.Domain(numpoints, xlim, ylim, zlim, rho0=1.0, c0=10, P0=None, gravity=None, actions=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Domain class for SpatialPy. A domain defines points and attributes of a regional space for simulation.

Parameters:

  • numpoints (int) – Total number of spatial domain points

  • xlim (float(2)) – Range of domain along x-axis

  • ylim (float(2)) – Range of domain along y-axis

  • zlim (float(2)) – Range of domain along z-axis

  • rho (float) – Background density for the system

  • c0 (float) – Speed of sound for the system

  • P0 (float) – Background pressure for the system

  • gravity (float[3]) – Acceleration of gravity for the system.

add_fill_action(lattice=None, geometry=None, cartesian=None, spherical=None, cylindrical=None, enable=True, apply_action=False, **props)[source]¶

Create an action that can add particles to the domain.

Parameters:

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying fill actions.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used when applying fill actions. Defaults to spatialpy.GeometryAll.

  • cartesian (dict) – Arguments used to create a cartesian lattice. Ignored if lattice is set.

  • spherical (dict) – Arguments used to create a spherical lattice. Ignored if lattice or cartesian is set.

  • cylindrical (dict) – Arguments used to create a spherical lattice. Ignored if lattice, cartesian, or spherical is set.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **props – Additional particle properties passed to Domain.add_point().

Returns:

Number of particles added to the domain if apply_action is true, else the fill action.

Return type:

int | dict

Raises:

DomainError – If a lattice wasn’t provided or could not be constructed.

add_point(point, vol=1, mass=1, type_id='UnAssigned', nu=0, fixed=False, rho=None, c=10)[source]¶

Add a single point particle to the domain space.

Parameters:

  • point (float(3)) – Spatial coordinate vertices of point to be added

  • vol (float) – Default volume of particle to be added

  • mass (float) – Default mass of particle to be added

  • type_id (str | int) – Particle type ID of particle to be craddedeated

  • nu (float) – Default viscosity of particle to be added

  • fixed (bool) – True if particle is spatially fixed, else False

  • c (float) – Default artificial speed of sound of particle to be added

  • rho (float) – Default density of particle to be added

Raises:

DomainError – Type_id is 0 or type_id contains an invalid character.

add_remove_action(geometry=None, enable=True, apply_action=False)[source]¶

Create an action that can remove particles from the domain.

Parameters:

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used when applying set actions. Defaults to spatialpy.GeometryAll.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

Returns:

The set action if apply_action is false.

Return type:

dict

add_set_action(geometry=None, enable=True, apply_action=False, **props)[source]¶

Create an action that can set particle properties for particles in the domain.

Parameters:

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used when applying set actions. Defaults to spatialpy.GeometryAll.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **props – Additional particle properties passed to Domain.add_point().

Returns:

The set action if apply_action is false.

Return type:

dict

Raises:

DomainError – If no additional properties are provided.

apply_actions(start=0, end=None, preserve_actions=False)[source]¶

Apply domain actions in order from start to end.

Parameters:

  • start (int) – Starting index for actions (inclusive).

  • end (int) – Ending index for actions (exclusive).

  • preserve_actions (bool) – If False, remove the action after its applied.

Raises:

DomainError – If the action is not supported.

apply_fill_action(action)[source]¶

Add particles within a region defined by the actions lattice and geometry to the domain. Particles will have attributes defined in the actions props.

Parameters:

action (dict) – Fill action containing a lattice, geometry, and particle properties. Example: {‘type’: ‘fill’, ‘lattice’: lattice_obj, ‘geometry’:geometry_obj, ‘props’:{}}

Raises:

DomainError – If action is not a fill action or is missing a lattice.

apply_remove_action(action)[source]¶

Remove particles within a domain region defined by the actions geometry.

Parameters:

action (dict) – Remove action containing a geometry. Example: {‘type’: ‘remove’, ‘geometry’:geometry_obj}

Raises:

DomainError – If action is not a set action, the actions geometry is an invalid type, the action is missing props, or type_id in props contains an invalid character or is an int < 0.

apply_set_action(action)[source]¶

Set properties of particles within a domain region defined by the actions geometry. Particles will have attributes defined in the actions props.

Parameters:

action (dict) – Set action containing a geometry and particle properties. Example: {‘type’: ‘set’, ‘geometry’:geometry_obj , ‘props’:{}}

Raises:

DomainError – If action is not a set action, the actions geometry is an invalid type, the action is missing props, or type_id in props contains an invalid character or is an int < 0.

DomainError – If a type_id is not set or rho=0 for a particle.

classmethod create_2D_domain(xlim, ylim, numx, numy, type_id=1, mass=1.0, nu=1.0, rho=None, c=0, fixed=False, enable=True, apply_action=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a filled 2D domain

Parameters:

  • xlim (float(2)) – highest and lowest coordinate in the x dimension

  • ylim (float(2)) – highest and lowest coordinate in the y dimension

  • numx (int) – number of particle spacing in the x dimension

  • numy (int) – number of particle spacing in the y dimension

  • type_id (int) – default type ID of particles to be created. Defaults to 1

  • mass (float) – default mass of particles to be created. Defaults to 1.0

  • nu (float) – default viscosity of particles to be created. Defaults to 1.0

  • c (float) – default artificial speed of sound of particles to be created. Defaults to 0.0.

  • rho (float) – default density of particles to be created.

  • fixed (bool) – spatially fixed flag of particles to be created. Defaults to false.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.

Returns:

Uniform 2D SpatialPy Domain object.

Return type:

spatialpy.core.domain.Domain

Create a filled 3D domain

  • ylim (float(2)) – highest and lowest coordinate in the y dimension

  • zlim (float(2)) – highest and lowest coordinate in the z dimension

  • numy (int) – number of particle spacing in the y dimension

  • numz (int) – number of particle spacing in the z dimension

  • type_id (int) – default type ID of particles to be created. Defaults to 1

  • mass (float) – default mass of particles to be created. Defaults to 1.0

  • nu (float) – default viscosity of particles to be created. Defaults to 1.0

  • c (float) – default artificial speed of sound of particles to be created. Defaults to 0.0.

  • rho (float) – default density of particles to be created.

  • fixed (bool) – spatially fixed flag of particles to be created. Defaults to false.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.

Returns:

Uniform 3D SpatialPy Domain object.

fill_with_particles(geometry_ivar, deltax, deltay=None, deltaz=None, xmin=None, xmax=None, ymin=None, ymax=None, zmin=None, zmax=None, enable=True, apply_action=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fill a region defined by a cartesian lattice and geometric shape with particles.

Parameters:

  • geometry_ivar (spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry) – an instance of a spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry subclass. The ‘inside()’ method of this object will be used to create add the particles.

  • deltax (float) – Distance between particles on the x-axis in a cartesian lattice.

  • deltay (float) – Distance between particles on the y-axis in a cartesian lattice.

  • deltaz (float) – Distance between particles on the z-axis in a cartesian lattice.

  • xmin (float) – Minimum x value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • xmax (float) – Maximum x value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • ymin (float) – Minimum y value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • ymax (float) – Maximum y value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • zmin (float) – Minimum z value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • zmax (float) – Maximum z value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.add_point().

Returns:

The number of particles that were created within this lattice and geometry.

Return type:

int

float

get_domain_size(update=False)[source]¶

Estimate of domain size at each vertex as the average of the diameters of the circumradius of the tetrahedrons that vertex is a part of.

Returns:

a numpy array containing the mean for each vertex based on all incident cells

Return type:

numpy.array

plot_types(width=None, height=None, colormap=None, size=None, title=None, included_types_list=None, use_matplotlib=False, return_plotly_figure=False)[source]¶

Plots the domain using plotly. Can only be viewed in a Jupyter Notebook.

Parameters:

  • width (int) – Width in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Default=500

  • height (int) – Height in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Default=500

  • colormap (str) – colormap to use. Plotly specification. valid values: “Plotly3”,”Jet”,”Blues”,”YlOrRd”, “PuRd”,”BuGn”,”YlOrBr”,”PuBuGn”,”BuPu”, “YlGnBu”, “PuBu”,”GnBu”,”YlGn”,”Greens”,”Reds”, “Greys”,”RdPu”,”OrRd”,”Purples”,”Oranges”.

  • size (int) – Size in pixels of the particle

  • title (str) – The title of the graph

  • included_types_list (list) – A list of ints describing which types to include. By default displays all types.

  • return_plotly_figure (bool) – Whether or not to return a figure dictionary of data(graph object traces) and layout options which may be edited by the user.

  • use_matplotlib (bool) – Whether or not to plot the proprties results using matplotlib.

Returns:

Plotly figure of domain types if, use_matplotlib=False and return_plotly_figure=True

Return type:

None or dict

  • end (int) – Ending index for actions (exclusive).

spatialpy.core.domain.Domain

set_properties(geometry_ivar, type_id, vol=None, mass=None, nu=None, rho=None, c=None, fixed=False, enable=True, apply_action=True)[source]¶

Add a type definition to the domain. By default, all regions are set to type 0.

Parameters:

  • geometry_ivar (spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry) – an instance of a spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry subclass. The ‘inside()’ method of this object will be used to assign properties to points.

  • type_id (str | int) – The identifier for this type.

  • vol (float) – The volume of each particle in the type.

  • mass (float) – The mass of each particle in the type.

  • rho (float) – The density of each particle in the type.

  • nu (float) – The viscosity of each particle in the type.

  • c (float) – The artificial speed of sound of each particle in the type.

  • fixed (bool) – Are the particles in this type immobile.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

Raises:

DomainError – Type_id is 0 or type_id contains an invalid character.

validate_action(action, coverage)[source]¶

Validate a domain action.

Parameters:

  • action (dict) – Domain action to be validated.

  • coverage (str) – Scope of the validation. Accepted values: ‘fill’, ‘set’, ‘remove’.

Raises:

DoaminError – If one of the following conditions are met: The action is an invalid type. The action’s geometry, lattice or props are not a valid type.

spatialpy.core.geometry module¶

class spatialpy.core.geometry.CombinatoryGeometry(formula, geo_namespace)[source]¶

Bases: object

Combinatory Geometry class uses one or more Geometry class for inclusion or exclusion of multiple geometric shapes.

Parameters:

  • formula (str) – Boolean logic formula to be evaluated. Example use: “(geo1 or geo2) and not geo3”.

  • geo_namespace (dict) – Namespace used when evaluating the formula. Example use: {‘geo1’: Geometry1(), ‘geo2’: Geometry2(), ‘geo3’: Geometry3()} where ‘geo1’, ‘geo2’, and ‘geo3’ are found in the formula.

inside(point, on_boundary)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • point (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coodinates for the particle.

  • on_boundary (bool) – Indicates whether a particle is on the edge of the domain.

Returns:

True if the particle satisfies boolean condition for all geometies, else False.

Return type:

bool

Raises:

GeometryError – If any geometries inside method does not return a bool.

spatialpy.core.initialcondition module¶

class spatialpy.core.initialcondition.InitialCondition[source]¶

Bases: object

Class used to defined initial conditions in SpatialPy. SubClasses must implement the ‘apply(model)’ method, which direction modifies the model.u0[species, voxel] matrix.

apply(model)[source]¶

Set the initial condition of the species to the count.

Parameters:

model (spatialpy.core.model.Model) – Model contianing the target species.

class spatialpy.core.initialcondition.PlaceInitialCondition(species, count, location)[source]¶

Bases: InitialCondition

Class used to defined the place initial condition in SpatialPy.

Parameters:

  • species (spatialpy.core.species.Species) – The species to set the initial condition.

  • count (int) – The initial condition for the target species.

  • location (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coordinates to place the initial condition.

apply(model)[source]¶

Set the initial condition of the species to the count at the location.

Parameters:

model (spatialpy.core.model.Model) – Model contianing the target species.

class spatialpy.core.initialcondition.ScatterInitialCondition(species, count, types=None)[source]¶

Bases: InitialCondition

Class used to defined the scatter initial condition in SpatialPy.

Parameters:

  • species (spatialpy.core.species.Species) – The species to set the initial condition.

  • count (int) – The initial condition for the target species.

  • types (list) – Types of the particles to place the initial condition.

apply(model)[source]¶

Scatter ‘count’ of ‘species’ randomly over the list of types (all types if None).

Parameters:

model (spatialpy.core.model.Model) – Model contianing the target species.

spatialpy.core.lattice module¶

class spatialpy.core.lattice.CartesianLattice(xmin, xmax, deltax, center=None, ymin=None, ymax=None, zmin=None, zmax=None, deltay=None, deltaz=None)[source]¶

Bases: Lattice

Cartesian lattice class provides a method for creating parts of the spatial

domain within a cartesian coordinate system.

Parameters:

  • center (float[3] | float(3)) – The center point of the lattice.

  • xmin (float) – Minimum x value of the lattice.

  • xmax (float) – Maximum x value of the lattice.

  • ymin (float) – Minimum y value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmin).

  • ymax (float) – Maximum y value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmax).

  • zmin (float) – Minimum z value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmin).

  • zmax (float) – Maximum z value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmax).

  • deltax (float) – Distance between two particles on the X-Axis.

  • deltay (float) – Distance between two particles on the Y-Axis (optional, defaults to deltax).

  • deltaz (float) – Distance between two particles on the Z-Axis (optional, defaults to deltax).

Raises:

LatticeError – if center is not and list, doesn’t contain 3 values, or any value is not a float.

apply(domain, geometry, transform=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Parameters:

  • transform (function) – Transformation function applied to each particle.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.add_point().

add(components)[source]¶

Adds a component, or list of components to the model. If a list is provided, Species and Parameters are added before other components. Lists may contain any combination of accepted types other than lists and do not need to be in any particular order.

Add a scalar spatial function to the simulation. This is useful if you have a spatially varying input to your model. Argument is a instances of subclass of the spatialpy.DataFunction class. It must implement a function ‘map(point)’ which takes a the spatial positon ‘point’ as an array, and it returns a float value.

run(number_of_trajectories=1, seed=None, timeout=None, number_of_threads=None, debug_level=0, debug=False, profile=False)[source]¶

Simulate the model. Returns a result object containing simulation results.

Parameters:

  • number_of_trajectories (int) – How many trajectories should be run.

  • seed (int) – The random seed given to the solver.

  • timeout (int) – Number of seconds for simulation to run. Simulation will be killed upon reaching timeout.

  • number_of_threads (int) – The number threads the solver will use.

  • debug_level (int) – Level of output from the solver: 0, 1, or 2. Default: 0.

  • debug (bool) – Optional flag to print out additional debug info during simulation.

  • profile (bool) – Optional flag to print out addtional performance profiling for simulation.

Returns:

A SpatialPy Result object containing simulation data.

Return type:

spatialpy.core.result.Result

spatialpy.core.parameter module¶

class spatialpy.core.parameter.Parameter(name=None, expression=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A parameter can be given as an expression (function) or directly as a value (scalar). If given an expression, it should be understood as evaluable in the namespace of a parent Model.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name by which this parameter is called or referenced.

  • expression (str) – String for a function calculating parameter values. Should be evaluable in namespace of Model.

Raises:

ParameterError – Arg is of invalid type. Required arg set to None. Arg value is outside of accepted bounds.

validate(expression=None, coverage='all')[source]¶

Validate the parameter.

Parameters:

  • expression (str) – String for a function calculating parameter values. Should be evaluable in namespace of Model.

  • coverage (str) – The scope of attributes to validate. Set to an attribute name to restrict validation to a specific attribute.

Raises:

ParameterError – Attribute is of invalid type. Required attribute set to None. Attribute value is outside of accepted bounds.

spatialpy.core.reaction module¶

class spatialpy.core.reaction.Reaction(name=None, reactants=None, products=None, propensity_function=None, ode_propensity_function=None, rate=None, annotation=None, restrict_to=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Models a biochemical reaction. A reaction conatains dictionaries of species (reactants and products) and a parameters. The reaction’s propensity functions needs to be evaluable (and result in a non-negative scalar value) in the namespace defined by the union of its Reactant and Product dictionaries and its Parameter. For mass-action, zeroth, first and second order reactions are supported, attempting to used higher orders will result in an error.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name by which the reaction is called (optional).

  • reactants (dict) – The reactants that are consumed in the reaction, with stoichiometry. An example would be {R1 : 1, R2 : 2} if the reaction consumes two of R1 and one of R2, where R1 and R2 are Species objects.

  • products (dict) – The species that are created by the reaction event, with stoichiometry. Same format as reactants.

  • propensity_function (str) – The custom propensity function for the reaction. Must be evaluable in the namespace of the reaction using C operations.

  • ode_propensity_function (str) – The custom ode propensity function for the reaction. Must be evaluable in the namespace of the reaction using C operations.

  • rate (float) – The rate of the mass-action reaction, take care to note the units.

  • annotation (str) – An optional note about the reaction.

  • restrict_to (int, str, list of ints or list of strs) – Restrict reaction execution to a type or list of types within the domain.

Notes

For a species that is NOT consumed in the reaction but is part of a mass action reaction, add it as both a reactant and a product.

Mass-action reactions must also have a rate term added. Note that the input rate represents the mass-action constant rate independent of volume.

if a name is not provided for reactions, the name will be populated by the model based on the order it was added. This could impact seeded simulation results if the order of addition is not preserved.

add_product(species, stoichiometry)[source]¶

Add a product to this reaction

Parameters:

  • stoichiometry (int) – Stoichiometry of this product.

  • products (dict) – The species that are created by the reaction event, with stoichiometry. Same format as reactants.

  • propensity_function (str) – The custom propensity function for the reaction. Must be evaluable in the namespace of the reaction using C operations.

  • ode_propensity_function (str) – The custom ode propensity function for the reaction. Must be evaluable in the namespace of the reaction using C operations.

spatialpy.core.result module¶

class spatialpy.core.result.Result(model=None, result_dir=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Result object for a URDME simulation.

export_to_csv(folder_name=None)[source]¶

Write the trajectory to a set of CSV files. The first, modelname_mesh.csv, specifies the mesh. The other files, modelname_species_S.csv, for species named S, specify trajectory data for each species. The columns of modelname_mesh.csv are: ‘Voxel ID’, ‘X’, ‘Y’, ‘Z’, ‘Type’, ‘Volume’, ‘Mass’, ‘Viscosity’ The columns of modelname_species_S.csv: ‘Time’, ‘Voxel 0’, Voxel 1’, … ‘Voxel N’.

Parameters:

folder_name (str) – A path where the vtk files will be written, created if non-existant. Defaults current working directory

get_property(property_name, timepoints=None)[source]¶

Get the property values for a given species in the model for one or all timepoints. If ‘timepoints’ is None (default), a matrix of dimension: (number of timepoints) x (number of voxels) is returned. If an integer value is given, that value is used to index into the timespan, and that time point is returned as a 1D array with size (number of voxel).

Parameters:

  • property_name (str) – A string describing the property to be returned. Can be one of: { ‘v’ : velocity, ‘rho’: density, ‘mass’: mass, ‘id’: type_id, ‘type’: type as str, ‘bvf_phi’: boundary volume fraction, ‘nu’: viscosity}

  • timepoints (int) – timespan index to be returned. Default is None

Returns:

a numpy array of target property values across timepoints, defaults to all timepoints.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Raises:

ResultError – Could not get data for given timepoints.

get_species(species, timepoints=None, concentration=False, deterministic=False, debug=False)[source]¶

Get the populations/concentration values for a given species in the model for one or all timepoints. Returns a numpy array containing the species population/concentration values.

Parameters:

  • species (str | spatialpy.core.species.Species) – A species in string or dictionary form to retreive information about

  • timepoints (int) – A time point where the information should be retreived from. If ‘timepoints’ is None (default), a matrix of dimension: (number of timepoints) x (number of voxels) is returned. If an integer value is given, that value is used to index into the timespan, and that time point is returned as a 1D array with size (number of voxel). Defaults to None

  • concentration (bool) – Whether or not the species is a concentration (True) or population (False) If concentration is False (default), the integer, raw, trajectory data is returned. If set to True, the concentration (=copy_number/volume) is returned. Defaults to False

  • deterministic (bool) – Whether or not the species is deterministic (True) or stochastic (False). Defaults to False

  • debug (bool) – Whether or not debug information should be printed. Defaults to False

Returns:

A numpy array containing population/concentration values for target species across specified timepoints. Defaults to all timepoints.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Raises:

ResultError – Unable to retrieve species data for given timepoints.

numpy.ndarray

plot_property(property_name, t_ndx=None, t_val=None, p_ndx=0, width=None, height=None, colormap=None, size=None, title=None, animated=False, t_ndx_list=None, speed=1, f_duration=500, t_duration=300, included_types_list=None, return_plotly_figure=False, use_matplotlib=False, debug=False)[source]¶

Plots the Results using plotly. Can only be viewed in a Jupyter Notebook.

Parameters:

  • property_name (str) – A string describing the property to be plotted.

  • t_ndx (int) – The time index of the results to be plotted

  • t_val (float) – The time value of the results to be plotted, ignored if animated is set to True

  • p_ndx (int) – The property index of the results to be plotted

  • width (int) – Width in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Defaults to 500 (Plotly) or 6.4 (MatPlotLib)

  • height (int) – Height in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Defaults to 500 (Plotly) or 4.8 (MatPlotLib)

  • colormap (str) – colormap to use. Plotly specification, valid values: “Plotly3”,”Jet”,”Blues”,”YlOrRd”, “PuRd”,”BuGn”,”YlOrBr”,”PuBuGn”,”BuPu”,”YlGnBu”, “PuBu”,”GnBu”,”YlGn”,”Greens”,”Reds”, “Greys”,”RdPu”,”OrRd”,”Purples”,”Oranges”.

  • size (int) – Size in pixels of the particle

  • title (str) – The title of the graph

  • animated (bool) – Whether or not the plot is a 3D animation, ignored if use_matplotlib True

  • t_ndx_list (list) – The list of time indeces of the results to be plotted, ignored if animated is False (default)

  • speed (int) – The interval of the time indeces of the results to be plotted (animated plots only)

  • f_duration (int) – The duration of time that a frame is displayed

  • t_duration (int) – The duration of time to execute the transition between frames

  • included_types_list (list) – A list of ints describing which types to include. By default displays all types.

  • return_plotly_figure (bool) – whether or not to return a figure dictionary of data (graph object traces) and layout options which may be edited by the user.

  • use_matplotlib (bool) – whether or not to plot the proprties results using matplotlib.

  • debug (bool) – output debugging info

Returns:

A dictionary representation of a plotly figure containing property data over given timepoints. Defaults to all timepoints.

Return type:

dict

Raises:

ResultError – Could not get property data for given timepoints.

plot_species(species, t_ndx=None, t_val=None, concentration=False, deterministic=False, width=None, height=None, colormap=None, size=5, title=None, animated=False, t_ndx_list=None, speed=1, f_duration=500, t_duration=300, return_plotly_figure=False, use_matplotlib=False, debug=False)[source]¶

Plots the Results using plotly or matplotlib. Can be viewed in a Jupyter Notebook.

If concentration is False (default), the integer, raw, trajectory data is returned, if set to True, the concentration (=copy_number/volume) is returned.

If deterministic is True, show results for determinstic (instead of stochastic) values

Parameters:

  • species (str) – A string describing the species to be plotted.

  • t_ndx (int) – The time index of the results to be plotted, ignored if animated is set to True

  • t_val (float) – The time value of the results to be plotted, ignored if animated is set to True

  • concentration (bool) – Whether or not to plot the data as stochastic concentration, ignored if deterministic is set to True

  • deterministic (bool) – Whether or not to plot the data as deterministic

  • width (int) – Width in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Defaults to 500 (Plotly) or 6.4 (MatPlotLib)

  • height (int) – Height in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Defaults to 500 (Plotly) or 4.8 (MatPlotLib)

  • colormap (str) – colormap to use. Plotly specification, valid values: “Plotly3”,”Jet”,”Blues”,”YlOrRd”, “PuRd”,”BuGn”,”YlOrBr”,”PuBuGn”,”BuPu”,”YlGnBu”, “PuBu”,”GnBu”,”YlGn”,”Greens”,”Reds”, “Greys”,”RdPu”,”OrRd”,”Purples”,”Oranges”.

  • size (int) – Size in pixels of the particle

  • title (str) – The title of the graph

  • animated (bool) – Whether or not the plot is a 3D animation, ignored if use_matplotlib True

  • t_ndx_list (list) – The list of time indeces of the results to be plotted, ignored if animated is False (default)

  • speed (int) – The interval of the time indeces of the results to be plotted (animated plots only)

  • f_duration (int) – The duration of time that a frame is displayed

  • t_duration (int) – The duration of time to execute the transition between frames

  • return_plotly_figure (bool) – whether or not to return a figure dictionary of data (graph object traces) and layout options which may be edited by the user.

  • use_matplotlib (bool) – whether or not to plot the proprties results using matplotlib.

  • debug (bool) – output debugging info

Returns:

A dictionary containing data for a plotly figure of species output trajectory

Return type:

dict

Raises:

ResultError – unable to plot species for given time

spatialpy.core.species module¶

class spatialpy.core.species.Species(name=None, diffusion_coefficient=None, restrict_to=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Model of a biochemical species. Must be assigned a diffusion coefficent.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the Species

  • diffusion_coefficient (float) – Non-constant coefficient of diffusion for Species.

  • restrict_to (int, str, list of ints or list of strs) – Set the diffusion coefficient to zero for ‘species’ in all types not in ‘listOfTypes’. This effectively restricts the movement of ‘species’ to the types specified in ‘listOfTypes’.

Raises:

SpeciesError – If diffusion_coefficient is negative or not a valid type.

spatialpy.core.timespan module¶

class spatialpy.core.timespan.TimeSpan(items, timestep_size=None)[source]¶

Bases: Iterator

Model timespan that describes the duration to run the simulation and at which timepoint to sample the species populations during the simulation.

Parameters:

  • items (list, tuple, range, or numpy.ndarray) – Evenly-spaced list of times at which to sample the species populations during the simulation. Best to use the form np.linspace(<start time>, <end time>, <number of time-points, inclusive>)

  • timestep_size (int | float) – Size of each timestep in seconds

Raises:

TimespanError – items is an invalid type.

classmethod arange(increment, t=20, timestep_size=None)[source]¶

Creates a timespan using the form np.arange(0, <t, inclusive>, <increment>).

Parameters:

  • increment (float | int) – Distance between sample points for the species populations during the simulation.

  • t (float | int) – End time for the simulation.

  • timestep_size (int | float) – Size of each timestep in seconds

Returns:

Timespan for the model.

Return type:

spatialpy.TimeSpan

Raises:

TimespanError – t or increment are None, <= 0, or invalid type.

classmethod linspace(t=20, num_points=None, timestep_size=None)[source]¶

Creates a timespan using the form np.linspace(0, <t>, <num_points, inclusive>).

Parameters:

  • t (float | int) – End time for the simulation.

  • num_points (int) – Number of sample points for the species populations during the simulation.

  • timestep_size (int | float) – Size of each timestep in seconds

Returns:

Timespan for the model.

Return type:

spatialpy.TimeSpan

Raises:

TimespanError – t or num_points are None, <= 0, or invalid type.

Validate the models time span

Parameters:

  • coverage (str) – The scope of attributes to validate. Set to an attribute name to restrict validation to a specific attribute.

Raises:

TimespanError – Timespan is an invalid type, empty, not uniform, contains a single repeated value, or contains a negative initial time.

spatialpy.core.transformation module¶

class spatialpy.core.transformation.ReflectionTransformation(point1, normal=None, point2=None, point3=None, geometry=None, lattice=None, transformation=None)[source]¶

Bases: Transformation

Reflection transformation class provides a methods for applying and reversing

reflection transformations around an arbitrary plane to parts the spatial domain.

Parameters:

  • normal (float[3]) – The normal of the arbitrary plane.

  • point1 (float[3]) – Point 1 on an arbitrary plane. Serves as the base for the normal

  • point2 (float[3]) – Point 2 on an arbitrary plane. Used with point 1 to create a vector on the plane.

  • point3 (float[3]) – Point 3 on an arbitrary plane. Used with point 1 to create a vector on the plane.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used once the transformation is reversed. Transformation.inside wraps Geometry.inside.

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying transformations. Transformation.apply wraps Lattice.apply.

  • transformation (spatialpy.Transformation) – Transformation to be applied after applying this transformation.

Raises:

TransformationError – if the provided Geometry, Lattice, or Transformation are invalid.

reverse_transform(point)[source]¶

Reverses the defined reflection transformation for the given point.

Parameters:

point (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coodinates for the particle.

Returns:

The point prior to any transformations.

Return type:

float[3]

Applies the defined reflection transformation to the given point.

Parameters:

point (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coodinates for the particle.

Returns:

The point prior to any transformations.

Return type:

float[3]

class spatialpy.core.transformation.RotationTransformation(vector, angle, geometry=None, lattice=None, transformation=None)[source]¶

Bases: Transformation

Rotation transformation class provides a methods for applying and reversing

rotation transformations around an arbitrary vector by a given angle to parts the spatial domain.

Parameters:

  • vector (list) – Arbitrary vector by which the region is rotated around. Basic example: [[2, 2, 3], [4, 5, 5]]

  • angle (float) – Angle by which to rotate the region.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used once the transformation is reversed. Transformation.inside wraps Geometry.inside.

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying transformations. Transformation.apply wraps Lattice.apply.

  • transformation (spatialpy.Transformation) – Transformation to be applied after applying this transformation.

Raises:

TransformationError – if the provided Geometry, Lattice, or Transformation are invalid.

Module contents¶

class spatialpy.core.BoundaryCondition(xmin=None, xmax=None, ymin=None, ymax=None, zmin=None, zmax=None, type_id=None, deterministic=True, target=None, value=None, model=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Set spatial regions of the domain where a property of particles are held constant (updated each simulation step)

Conditions (one or more of the following must be set):

  • xmin, xmax: (float) min or max value in the x dimension

  • ymin, ymax: (float) min or max value in the y dimension

  • zmin, zmax: (float) min or max value in the z dimension

  • type_id: type (subdomain) of the partciles

Targets (one of the following must be set):

property: (str), ‘nu’, ‘rho’,’v’ species: (str) name of a chemical species. Must also set deterministic=True/False flag.

Parameters:

  • xmin (float) – x-axis coordinate lower bound of condition

  • xmax (float) – x-axis coordinate upper bound of condition

  • ymin (float) – y-axis coordinate lower bound of condition

  • ymax (float) – y-axis coordinate upper bound of condition

  • zmin (float) – z-axis coordinate lower bound of condition

  • zmax (float) – z-axis coordinate upper bound of condition

  • type_id (int | str) – Set condition to particle type id

  • deterministic (bool) – Must be set if target is Species. Set True if boundary condition target is species and applies to deterministic simulation. BoundaryCondition not yet implemeneted for Stochastic Species.

  • target (str) – Set target to properties, can be ‘nu’ ‘rho’ or ‘v’ or species name If species name, determinstic must also be set to True/False.

  • value (float or float[3]) – Value property will take in region defined by the conditions

  • model (spatialpy.core.model.Model) – Target model of boundary condition

expression()[source]¶

Creates evaluable string expression of boundary condition.

Returns:

A string representation of the boundary condition.

Return type:

str

exception spatialpy.core.BoundaryConditionError[source]¶

Bases: ModelError

Base class for exceptions in the boundarycondition module.

class spatialpy.core.CartesianLattice(xmin, xmax, deltax, center=None, ymin=None, ymax=None, zmin=None, zmax=None, deltay=None, deltaz=None)[source]¶

Bases: Lattice

Cartesian lattice class provides a method for creating parts of the spatial

domain within a cartesian coordinate system.

Parameters:

  • center (float[3] | float(3)) – The center point of the lattice.

  • xmin (float) – Minimum x value of the lattice.

  • xmax (float) – Maximum x value of the lattice.

  • ymin (float) – Minimum y value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmin).

  • ymax (float) – Maximum y value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmax).

  • zmin (float) – Minimum z value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmin).

  • zmax (float) – Maximum z value of the lattice (optional, defaults to xmax).

  • deltax (float) – Distance between two particles on the X-Axis.

  • deltay (float) – Distance between two particles on the Y-Axis (optional, defaults to deltax).

  • deltaz (float) – Distance between two particles on the Z-Axis (optional, defaults to deltax).

Raises:

LatticeError – if center is not and list, doesn’t contain 3 values, or any value is not a float.

apply(domain, geometry, transform=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fill a domain with particles within the cartesian lattice restricted by the geometry.

Parameters:

  • domain (spatialpy.Domain) – Domain particles are to be added to.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry | spatialpy.CombinatoryGeometry) – Geometry defining the region within the lattice in which particles are restricted to.

  • transform (function) – Transformation function applied to each particle.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.add_point().

validate()[source]¶

Validate the cartesian lattice dependencies.

class spatialpy.core.CombinatoryGeometry(formula, geo_namespace)[source]¶

Bases: object

Combinatory Geometry class uses one or more Geometry class for inclusion or exclusion of multiple geometric shapes.

Parameters:

  • formula (str) – Boolean logic formula to be evaluated. Example use: “(geo1 or geo2) and not geo3”.

  • geo_namespace (dict) – Namespace used when evaluating the formula. Example use: {‘geo1’: Geometry1(), ‘geo2’: Geometry2(), ‘geo3’: Geometry3()} where ‘geo1’, ‘geo2’, and ‘geo3’ are found in the formula.

inside(point, on_boundary)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • point (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coodinates for the particle.

  • on_boundary (bool) – Indicates whether a particle is on the edge of the domain.

Returns:

True if the particle satisfies boolean condition for all geometies, else False.

Return type:

bool

Raises:

GeometryError – If any geometries inside method does not return a bool.

Bases: Lattice

Cylindrical lattice class provides a method for creating parts of the spatial

domain within a cylindrical coordinate system.

Parameters:

  • length (float) – Length of the cylindrical lattice.

  • radius (float) – Distance between the center and the surface.

map(point)[source]¶

This method must be overridden by the DataFunction subclass.

NOTE: The spatial location is evaulated at t=0 and is not re-evaluated as the fluid domain moves over time.

Parameters:

point (float[3]) – The x, y, z position.

Returns:

Value of function at this spatial location.

Return type:

float

exception spatialpy.core.DataFunctionError[source]¶

Bases: ModelError

Class for exceptions in the datafunction module.

class spatialpy.core.Domain(numpoints, xlim, ylim, zlim, rho0=1.0, c0=10, P0=None, gravity=None, actions=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Domain class for SpatialPy. A domain defines points and attributes of a regional space for simulation.

Parameters:

  • numpoints (int) – Total number of spatial domain points

  • xlim (float(2)) – Range of domain along x-axis

  • ylim (float(2)) – Range of domain along y-axis

  • zlim (float(2)) – Range of domain along z-axis

  • rho (float) – Background density for the system

  • c0 (float) – Speed of sound for the system

  • P0 (float) – Background pressure for the system

  • gravity (float[3]) – Acceleration of gravity for the system.

add_fill_action(lattice=None, geometry=None, cartesian=None, spherical=None, cylindrical=None, enable=True, apply_action=False, **props)[source]¶

Create an action that can add particles to the domain.

Parameters:

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying fill actions.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used when applying fill actions. Defaults to spatialpy.GeometryAll.

  • cartesian (dict) – Arguments used to create a cartesian lattice. Ignored if lattice is set.

  • spherical (dict) – Arguments used to create a spherical lattice. Ignored if lattice or cartesian is set.

  • cylindrical (dict) – Arguments used to create a spherical lattice. Ignored if lattice, cartesian, or spherical is set.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **props – Additional particle properties passed to Domain.add_point().

Returns:

Number of particles added to the domain if apply_action is true, else the fill action.

Return type:

int | dict

Raises:

DomainError – If a lattice wasn’t provided or could not be constructed.

add_point(point, vol=1, mass=1, type_id='UnAssigned', nu=0, fixed=False, rho=None, c=10)[source]¶

Add a single point particle to the domain space.

Parameters:

  • point (float(3)) – Spatial coordinate vertices of point to be added

  • vol (float) – Default volume of particle to be added

  • mass (float) – Default mass of particle to be added

  • type_id (str | int) – Particle type ID of particle to be craddedeated

  • nu (float) – Default viscosity of particle to be added

  • fixed (bool) – True if particle is spatially fixed, else False

  • c (float) – Default artificial speed of sound of particle to be added

  • rho (float) – Default density of particle to be added

Raises:

DomainError – Type_id is 0 or type_id contains an invalid character.

Apply domain actions in order from start to end.

  • end (int) – Ending index for actions (exclusive).

DomainError – If the action is not supported.

apply_fill_action(action)[source]¶

Add particles within a region defined by the actions lattice and geometry to the domain. Particles will have attributes defined in the actions props.

Parameters:

action (dict) – Fill action containing a lattice, geometry, and particle properties. Example: {‘type’: ‘fill’, ‘lattice’: lattice_obj, ‘geometry’:geometry_obj, ‘props’:{}}

Raises:

DomainError – If action is not a fill action or is missing a lattice.

apply_remove_action(action)[source]¶

Remove particles within a domain region defined by the actions geometry.

Parameters:

action (dict) – Remove action containing a geometry. Example: {‘type’: ‘remove’, ‘geometry’:geometry_obj}

Raises:

DomainError – If action is not a set action, the actions geometry is an invalid type, the action is missing props, or type_id in props contains an invalid character or is an int < 0.

apply_set_action(action)[source]¶

Set properties of particles within a domain region defined by the actions geometry. Particles will have attributes defined in the actions props.

action (dict) – Set action containing a geometry and particle properties. Example: {‘type’: ‘set’, ‘geometry’:geometry_obj , ‘props’:{}}

Raises:

DomainError – If action is not a set action, the actions geometry is an invalid type, the action is missing props, or type_id in props contains an invalid character or is an int < 0.

classmethod create_2D_domain(xlim, ylim, numx, numy, type_id=1, mass=1.0, nu=1.0, rho=None, c=0, fixed=False, enable=True, apply_action=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a filled 2D domain

Parameters:

  • xlim (float(2)) – highest and lowest coordinate in the x dimension

  • ylim (float(2)) – highest and lowest coordinate in the y dimension

  • numx (int) – number of particle spacing in the x dimension

  • numy (int) – number of particle spacing in the y dimension

  • type_id (int) – default type ID of particles to be created. Defaults to 1

  • mass (float) – default mass of particles to be created. Defaults to 1.0

  • nu (float) – default viscosity of particles to be created. Defaults to 1.0

  • c (float) – default artificial speed of sound of particles to be created. Defaults to 0.0.

  • rho (float) – default density of particles to be created.

  • fixed (bool) – spatially fixed flag of particles to be created. Defaults to false.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.

Returns:

Uniform 2D SpatialPy Domain object.

Return type:

spatialpy.core.domain.Domain

fill_with_particles(geometry_ivar, deltax, deltay=None, deltaz=None, xmin=None, xmax=None, ymin=None, ymax=None, zmin=None, zmax=None, enable=True, apply_action=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fill a region defined by a cartesian lattice and geometric shape with particles.

Parameters:

  • geometry_ivar (spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry) – an instance of a spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry subclass. The ‘inside()’ method of this object will be used to create add the particles.

  • deltax (float) – Distance between particles on the x-axis in a cartesian lattice.

  • deltay (float) – Distance between particles on the y-axis in a cartesian lattice.

  • deltaz (float) – Distance between particles on the z-axis in a cartesian lattice.

  • xmin (float) – Minimum x value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • xmax (float) – Maximum x value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • ymin (float) – Minimum y value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • ymax (float) – Maximum y value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • zmin (float) – Minimum z value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • zmax (float) – Maximum z value of the bounding box in a cartesian lattice.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.add_point().

Returns:

The number of particles that were created within this lattice and geometry.

Return type:

int

plot_types(width=None, height=None, colormap=None, size=None, title=None, included_types_list=None, use_matplotlib=False, return_plotly_figure=False)[source]¶

Plots the domain using plotly. Can only be viewed in a Jupyter Notebook.

Parameters:

  • width (int) – Width in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Default=500

  • height (int) – Height in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Default=500

  • colormap (str) – colormap to use. Plotly specification. valid values: “Plotly3”,”Jet”,”Blues”,”YlOrRd”, “PuRd”,”BuGn”,”YlOrBr”,”PuBuGn”,”BuPu”, “YlGnBu”, “PuBu”,”GnBu”,”YlGn”,”Greens”,”Reds”, “Greys”,”RdPu”,”OrRd”,”Purples”,”Oranges”.

  • size (int) – Size in pixels of the particle

  • title (str) – The title of the graph

  • included_types_list (list) – A list of ints describing which types to include. By default displays all types.

  • return_plotly_figure (bool) – Whether or not to return a figure dictionary of data(graph object traces) and layout options which may be edited by the user.

  • use_matplotlib (bool) – Whether or not to plot the proprties results using matplotlib.

Returns:

Plotly figure of domain types if, use_matplotlib=False and return_plotly_figure=True

Return type:

None or dict

set_properties(geometry_ivar, type_id, vol=None, mass=None, nu=None, rho=None, c=None, fixed=False, enable=True, apply_action=True)[source]¶

Add a type definition to the domain. By default, all regions are set to type 0.

Parameters:

  • geometry_ivar (spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry) – an instance of a spatialpy.core.geometry.Geometry subclass. The ‘inside()’ method of this object will be used to assign properties to points.

  • type_id (str | int) – The identifier for this type.

  • vol (float) – The volume of each particle in the type.

  • mass (float) – The mass of each particle in the type.

  • rho (float) – The density of each particle in the type.

  • nu (float) – The viscosity of each particle in the type.

  • c (float) – The artificial speed of sound of each particle in the type.

  • fixed (bool) – Are the particles in this type immobile.

  • enable (bool) – Indicates that the action is to be applied by Domain.apply_actions.

  • apply_action (bool) – If true, apply the action, else, add the action to Domain.actions

Raises:

DomainError – Type_id is 0 or type_id contains an invalid character.

Raises:

add(components)[source]¶

Adds a component, or list of components to the model. If a list is provided, Species and Parameters are added before other components. Lists may contain any combination of accepted types other than lists and do not need to be in any particular order.

Parameters:

components (Species, Parameters, Reactions, Domain, Data Function, Initial Conditions, Boundary Conditions, and TimeSpan or list) – The component or list of components to be added the the model.

Returns:

The components that were added to the model.

Species, Parameters, Reactions, Domain, Data Function, Initial Conditions, Boundary Conditions, TimeSpan, or list

Raises:

ModelError – Component is invalid.

add_data_function(data_function)[source]¶

Add a scalar spatial function to the simulation. This is useful if you have a spatially varying input to your model. Argument is a instances of subclass of the spatialpy.DataFunction class. It must implement a function ‘map(point)’ which takes a the spatial positon ‘point’ as an array, and it returns a float value.

Parameters:

data_function (spatialpy.DataFunction) – Data function to be added.

DataFunction object(s) added tothe model.

run(number_of_trajectories=1, seed=None, timeout=None, number_of_threads=None, debug_level=0, debug=False, profile=False)[source]¶

Simulate the model. Returns a result object containing simulation results.

Parameters:

  • number_of_trajectories (int) – How many trajectories should be run.

  • seed (int) – The random seed given to the solver.

  • timeout (int) – Number of seconds for simulation to run. Simulation will be killed upon reaching timeout.

  • number_of_threads (int) – The number threads the solver will use.

  • debug_level (int) – Level of output from the solver: 0, 1, or 2. Default: 0.

  • debug (bool) – Optional flag to print out additional debug info during simulation.

  • profile (bool) – Optional flag to print out addtional performance profiling for simulation.

Returns:

A SpatialPy Result object containing simulation data.

Return type:

spatialpy.core.result.Result

class spatialpy.core.Parameter(name=None, expression=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A parameter can be given as an expression (function) or directly as a value (scalar). If given an expression, it should be understood as evaluable in the namespace of a parent Model.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name by which this parameter is called or referenced.

  • expression (str) – String for a function calculating parameter values. Should be evaluable in namespace of Model.

Raises:

ParameterError – Arg is of invalid type. Required arg set to None. Arg value is outside of accepted bounds.

  • coverage (str) – The scope of attributes to validate. Set to an attribute name to restrict validation to a specific attribute.

Raises:

ParameterError – Attribute is of invalid type. Required attribute set to None. Attribute value is outside of accepted bounds.

class spatialpy.core.Reaction(name=None, reactants=None, products=None, propensity_function=None, ode_propensity_function=None, rate=None, annotation=None, restrict_to=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Models a biochemical reaction. A reaction conatains dictionaries of species (reactants and products) and a parameters. The reaction’s propensity functions needs to be evaluable (and result in a non-negative scalar value) in the namespace defined by the union of its Reactant and Product dictionaries and its Parameter. For mass-action, zeroth, first and second order reactions are supported, attempting to used higher orders will result in an error.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name by which the reaction is called (optional).

  • reactants (dict) – The reactants that are consumed in the reaction, with stoichiometry. An example would be {R1 : 1, R2 : 2} if the reaction consumes two of R1 and one of R2, where R1 and R2 are Species objects.

  • products (dict) – The species that are created by the reaction event, with stoichiometry. Same format as reactants.

  • propensity_function (str) – The custom propensity function for the reaction. Must be evaluable in the namespace of the reaction using C operations.

  • ode_propensity_function (str) – The custom ode propensity function for the reaction. Must be evaluable in the namespace of the reaction using C operations.

  • rate (float) – The rate of the mass-action reaction, take care to note the units.

  • annotation (str) – An optional note about the reaction.

  • restrict_to (int, str, list of ints or list of strs) – Restrict reaction execution to a type or list of types within the domain.

Notes

For a species that is NOT consumed in the reaction but is part of a mass action reaction, add it as both a reactant and a product.

Mass-action reactions must also have a rate term added. Note that the input rate represents the mass-action constant rate independent of volume.

if a name is not provided for reactions, the name will be populated by the model based on the order it was added. This could impact seeded simulation results if the order of addition is not preserved.

add_product(species, stoichiometry)[source]¶

Add a product to this reaction

Parameters:

  • species (spatialpy.core.species.Species) – Species object to be produced by the reaction

  • stoichiometry (int) – Stoichiometry of this product.

  • stoichiometry (int) – Stoichiometry of this participant reactant

  • products (dict) – The species that are created by the reaction event, with stoichiometry. Same format as reactants.

  • propensity_function (str) – The custom propensity function for the reaction. Must be evaluable in the namespace of the reaction using C operations.

class spatialpy.core.ReflectionTransformation(point1, normal=None, point2=None, point3=None, geometry=None, lattice=None, transformation=None)[source]¶

Bases: Transformation

Reflection transformation class provides a methods for applying and reversing

reflection transformations around an arbitrary plane to parts the spatial domain.

Parameters:

  • normal (float[3]) – The normal of the arbitrary plane.

  • point1 (float[3]) – Point 1 on an arbitrary plane. Serves as the base for the normal

  • point2 (float[3]) – Point 2 on an arbitrary plane. Used with point 1 to create a vector on the plane.

  • point3 (float[3]) – Point 3 on an arbitrary plane. Used with point 1 to create a vector on the plane.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used once the transformation is reversed. Transformation.inside wraps Geometry.inside.

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying transformations. Transformation.apply wraps Lattice.apply.

  • transformation (spatialpy.Transformation) – Transformation to be applied after applying this transformation.

Raises:

TransformationError – if the provided Geometry, Lattice, or Transformation are invalid.

export_to_csv(folder_name=None)[source]¶

Write the trajectory to a set of CSV files. The first, modelname_mesh.csv, specifies the mesh. The other files, modelname_species_S.csv, for species named S, specify trajectory data for each species. The columns of modelname_mesh.csv are: ‘Voxel ID’, ‘X’, ‘Y’, ‘Z’, ‘Type’, ‘Volume’, ‘Mass’, ‘Viscosity’ The columns of modelname_species_S.csv: ‘Time’, ‘Voxel 0’, Voxel 1’, … ‘Voxel N’.

Parameters:

folder_name (str) – A path where the vtk files will be written, created if non-existant. Defaults current working directory

get_property(property_name, timepoints=None)[source]¶

Get the property values for a given species in the model for one or all timepoints. If ‘timepoints’ is None (default), a matrix of dimension: (number of timepoints) x (number of voxels) is returned. If an integer value is given, that value is used to index into the timespan, and that time point is returned as a 1D array with size (number of voxel).

Parameters:

  • property_name (str) – A string describing the property to be returned. Can be one of: { ‘v’ : velocity, ‘rho’: density, ‘mass’: mass, ‘id’: type_id, ‘type’: type as str, ‘bvf_phi’: boundary volume fraction, ‘nu’: viscosity}

  • timepoints (int) – timespan index to be returned. Default is None

Returns:

a numpy array of target property values across timepoints, defaults to all timepoints.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Raises:

ResultError – Could not get data for given timepoints.

get_species(species, timepoints=None, concentration=False, deterministic=False, debug=False)[source]¶

Get the populations/concentration values for a given species in the model for one or all timepoints. Returns a numpy array containing the species population/concentration values.

Parameters:

  • species (str | spatialpy.core.species.Species) – A species in string or dictionary form to retreive information about

  • timepoints (int) – A time point where the information should be retreived from. If ‘timepoints’ is None (default), a matrix of dimension: (number of timepoints) x (number of voxels) is returned. If an integer value is given, that value is used to index into the timespan, and that time point is returned as a 1D array with size (number of voxel). Defaults to None

  • concentration (bool) – Whether or not the species is a concentration (True) or population (False) If concentration is False (default), the integer, raw, trajectory data is returned. If set to True, the concentration (=copy_number/volume) is returned. Defaults to False

  • deterministic (bool) – Whether or not the species is deterministic (True) or stochastic (False). Defaults to False

  • debug (bool) – Whether or not debug information should be printed. Defaults to False

Returns:

A numpy array containing population/concentration values for target species across specified timepoints. Defaults to all timepoints.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Raises:

ResultError – Unable to retrieve species data for given timepoints.

Returns:

A numpy array of the timespan containing all output time points.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

plot_property(property_name, t_ndx=None, t_val=None, p_ndx=0, width=None, height=None, colormap=None, size=None, title=None, animated=False, t_ndx_list=None, speed=1, f_duration=500, t_duration=300, included_types_list=None, return_plotly_figure=False, use_matplotlib=False, debug=False)[source]¶

Plots the Results using plotly. Can only be viewed in a Jupyter Notebook.

Parameters:

  • property_name (str) – A string describing the property to be plotted.

  • t_ndx (int) – The time index of the results to be plotted

  • t_val (float) – The time value of the results to be plotted, ignored if animated is set to True

  • p_ndx (int) – The property index of the results to be plotted

  • width (int) – Width in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Defaults to 500 (Plotly) or 6.4 (MatPlotLib)

  • height (int) – Height in pixels of output plot box or for matplotlib inches of output plot box. Defaults to 500 (Plotly) or 4.8 (MatPlotLib)

  • colormap (str) – colormap to use. Plotly specification, valid values: “Plotly3”,”Jet”,”Blues”,”YlOrRd”, “PuRd”,”BuGn”,”YlOrBr”,”PuBuGn”,”BuPu”,”YlGnBu”, “PuBu”,”GnBu”,”YlGn”,”Greens”,”Reds”, “Greys”,”RdPu”,”OrRd”,”Purples”,”Oranges”.

  • size (int) – Size in pixels of the particle

  • title (str) – The title of the graph

  • animated (bool) – Whether or not the plot is a 3D animation, ignored if use_matplotlib True

  • t_ndx_list (list) – The list of time indeces of the results to be plotted, ignored if animated is False (default)

  • speed (int) – The interval of the time indeces of the results to be plotted (animated plots only)

  • f_duration (int) – The duration of time that a frame is displayed

  • t_duration (int) – The duration of time to execute the transition between frames

  • included_types_list (list) – A list of ints describing which types to include. By default displays all types.

  • return_plotly_figure (bool) – whether or not to return a figure dictionary of data (graph object traces) and layout options which may be edited by the user.

  • use_matplotlib (bool) – whether or not to plot the proprties results using matplotlib.

  • debug (bool) – output debugging info

Returns:

A dictionary representation of a plotly figure containing property data over given timepoints. Defaults to all timepoints.

Return type:

dict

Raises:

ResultError – Could not get property data for given timepoints.

  • size (int) – Size in pixels of the particle

  • title (str) – The title of the graph

class spatialpy.core.RotationTransformation(vector, angle, geometry=None, lattice=None, transformation=None)[source]¶

Bases: Transformation

Rotation transformation class provides a methods for applying and reversing

rotation transformations around an arbitrary vector by a given angle to parts the spatial domain.

Parameters:

  • vector (list) – Arbitrary vector by which the region is rotated around. Basic example: [[2, 2, 3], [4, 5, 5]]

  • angle (float) – Angle by which to rotate the region.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used once the transformation is reversed. Transformation.inside wraps Geometry.inside.

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying transformations. Transformation.apply wraps Lattice.apply.

  • transformation (spatialpy.Transformation) – Transformation to be applied after applying this transformation.

Raises:

TransformationError – if the provided Geometry, Lattice, or Transformation are invalid.

reverse_transform(point)[source]¶

Reverses the defined rotation transformation for the given point.

Parameters:

point (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coodinates for the particle.

The point prior to any transformations.

class spatialpy.core.Species(name=None, diffusion_coefficient=None, restrict_to=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Model of a biochemical species. Must be assigned a diffusion coefficent.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the Species

  • diffusion_coefficient (float) – Non-constant coefficient of diffusion for Species.

  • restrict_to (int, str, list of ints or list of strs) – Set the diffusion coefficient to zero for ‘species’ in all types not in ‘listOfTypes’. This effectively restricts the movement of ‘species’ to the types specified in ‘listOfTypes’.

Bases: ModelError

Class for exceptions in the species module.

class spatialpy.core.SphericalLattice(radius, deltas, center=None, deltar=None)[source]¶

Bases: Lattice

Spherical lattice class provides a method for creating parts of the spatial

domain within a spherical coordinate system.

Parameters:

  • center (float[3] | float(3)) – The center point of the lattice.

  • radius (float) – Distance between the center and the surface.

  • deltas (float) – Distance between two particle on the surface.

  • deltar (float) – Radial distance between two particles.

Raises:

LatticeError – if center is not and list, doesn’t contain 3 values, or any value is not a float.

apply(domain, geometry, transform=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fill a domain with particles within the spherical lattice restricted by the geometry.

Parameters:

  • domain (spatialpy.Domain) – Domain particles are to be added to.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry | spatialpy.CombinatoryGeometry) – Geometry defining the region within the lattice in which particles are restricted to.

  • transform (function) – Transformation function applied to each particle.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.add_point().

validate()[source]¶

Validate the spherical lattice dependencies.

class spatialpy.core.TimeSpan(items, timestep_size=None)[source]¶

Bases: Iterator

Model timespan that describes the duration to run the simulation and at which timepoint to sample the species populations during the simulation.

Parameters:

  • items (list, tuple, range, or numpy.ndarray) – Evenly-spaced list of times at which to sample the species populations during the simulation. Best to use the form np.linspace(<start time>, <end time>, <number of time-points, inclusive>)

  • timestep_size (int | float) – Size of each timestep in seconds

Raises:

TimespanError – items is an invalid type.

classmethod arange(increment, t=20, timestep_size=None)[source]¶

Creates a timespan using the form np.arange(0, <t, inclusive>, <increment>).

Parameters:

  • increment (float | int) – Distance between sample points for the species populations during the simulation.

  • t (float | int) – End time for the simulation.

  • timestep_size (int | float) – Size of each timestep in seconds

Returns:

Timespan for the model.

Return type:

spatialpy.TimeSpan

Raises:

TimespanError – t or increment are None, <= 0, or invalid type.

classmethod linspace(t=20, num_points=None, timestep_size=None)[source]¶

Creates a timespan using the form np.linspace(0, <t>, <num_points, inclusive>).

Parameters:

  • t (float | int) – End time for the simulation.

  • num_points (int) – Number of sample points for the species populations during the simulation.

  • timestep_size (int | float) – Size of each timestep in seconds

Returns:

Timespan for the model.

Return type:

spatialpy.TimeSpan

Raises:

TimespanError – t or num_points are None, <= 0, or invalid type.

validate(items=None, timestep_size=None, coverage='build')[source]¶

Validate the models time span

Parameters:

  • timestep_size (int | float) – Size of each timestep in seconds

  • coverage (str) – The scope of attributes to validate. Set to an attribute name to restrict validation to a specific attribute.

Raises:

TimespanError – Timespan is an invalid type, empty, not uniform, contains a single repeated value, or contains a negative initial time.

Bases: ModelError

class spatialpy.core.Transformation(geometry=None, lattice=None, transformation=None, skip_validate=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Transformation class provides a methods for applying and reversing

transformations to parts the spatial domain.

Parameters:

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used once the transformation is reversed. Transformation.inside wraps Geometry.inside.

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying transformations. Transformation.apply wraps Lattice.apply.

  • transformation (spatialpy.Transformation) – Transformation to be applied after applying this transformation.

Raises:

TransformationError – if the provided Geometry, Lattice, or Transformation are invalid.

apply(domain, geometry, **kwargs)[source]¶
Wrapper for Lattice.apply that passes in a transformation function used to transform

particles within the region defined by the lattice and geometry.

Parameters:

  • domain (spatialpy.Domain) – Domain particles are to be added to.

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry | spatialpy.CombinatoryGeometry) – Geometry defining the region within the lattice in which particles are restricted to.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.add_point().

Returns:

The results of Lattice.apply.

Return type:

int

Raises:

TransformationError – if a lattice was not provided.

inside(point, on_boundary)[source]¶

Wrapper for Geometry.inside.

Parameters:

  • point (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coodinates for the particle.

  • on_boundary (bool) – Indicates whether a particle is on the edge of the domain.

Returns:

The results of Geometry.inside.

Return type:

bool

Raises:

TransformationError – if a geometry was not provided.

class spatialpy.core.TranslationTransformation(vector, geometry=None, lattice=None, transformation=None)[source]¶

Bases: Transformation

Translation transformation class provides a methods for applying and reversing

translation transformations by an arbitrary vector to parts the spatial domain.

Parameters:

  • vector (list) – Arbitrary vector by which the region is translated by. Basic example: [[2, 2, 3], [4, 5, 5]]

  • geometry (spatialpy.Geometry) – Geometry classed used once the transformation is reversed. Transformation.inside wraps Geometry.inside.

  • lattice (spatialpy.Lattice) – Lattice classed used when applying transformations. Transformation.apply wraps Lattice.apply.

  • transformation (spatialpy.Transformation) – Transformation to be applied after applying this transformation.

Raises:

TransformationError – if the provided Geometry, Lattice, or Transformation are invalid.

reverse_transform(point)[source]¶

Reverses the defined rotation transformation for the given point.

Parameters:

point (float[3]) – X, Y, Z coodinates for the particle.

Returns:

The point prior to any transformations.

Return type:

float[3]

Returns:

The point prior to any transformations.

class spatialpy.core.XMLMeshLattice(filename, center=None, subdomain_file=None, type_ids=None)[source]¶

Bases: Lattice

XML mesh lattice class provides a method for creating parts of the spatial

domain with a mesh defined by a FEniCS/dolfin style XML mesh file.

Parameters:

  • center (float[3] | float(3)) – The center point of the lattice.

  • filename (str) – Name of file to read.

  • subdomain_file (str) – StochSS v1.x subdomain description filename (optional).

  • type_ids (dict{str:str}) – Mapping of type indices to type names (optional).

  • transform (function) – Transformation function applied to each particle.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to Domain.add_point().
